sub_title: Electricity Market Analyst, Long-term Grid Planning
summary:
♻️ I started my career as a chemical engineer in the mining industry in sunny Western Australia. While the work was interesting I always had a passion for sustainability and given that mining isn’t exactly the most environmentally friendly thing to do (and frustrated with how slowly the Australian government was taking action on climate change at that time), I decided to come study renewable energy in Europe where climate change was being taken seriously. After travelling through many countries (and picking up a MSc in Finland and PhD in the Netherlands along the way), I’m now at TenneT - the Dutch and German Transmission System Operator (TSO)- where I work on paving the way towards a reliable, affordable, and sustainable power and energy system. 

⚡️A key focus of mine is security of supply, and I’m part of the team conducting TenneT’s annual security of supply analysis for the Netherlands (the Monitoring Leveringszekerheid), as well as the European Resource Adequacy Assessment (ERAA) in collaboration with other TSOs as part of ENTSO-E. I also (co-)led our Adequacy Outlook study exploring long-term resource adequacy in a net-zero emission Dutch and German energy system, and the important role firm capacity resources such as demand-side response, cross-border transmission, storage and low-carbon energy carriers like hydrogen could play in the future energy system, alongside solar and wind. 

🔍 Another aspect of my work involves analyzing the economic viability of capacity resources to ensure that the scenarios we consider for the future power system are as robust as possible, and identifying potential risks to resource adequacy amidst challenging market conditions. I’m also heavily involved in the ongoing Bidding Zone Review and other market-design related topics.

🤝 Decarbonizing the energy system is a massive challenge, especially given we may only have a little over 20 years to do it. Every country on the planet is facing the same issue and while they may have slightly different ways of solving the problem, I’m convinced that by sharing our insights and thinking out the thorny issues together, we can get there faster and avoid making the same mistakes. That’s why I’m here on LinkedIn, so feel free to reach out. I’m not the most active poster nor timely replier myself, but I’m working on it 😅

profile_positions.description:
I joined the Copernicus Institute to pursue my PhD in the field of energy system analysis. I used Power System modelling to investigate the long-term technical and economic feasibility of the European power system with increasing penetration of intermittent renewable energy sources. In particular, I focussed on the integration costs of variable renewable energy sources (iRES), optimum use of complementary technologies for iRES (e.g CCS, energy storage, interconnection capacity), and stability of the power system.

You can find my PhD thesis - Paris Proof Power: Exploring the impacts of different decarbonisation strategies in the European electricity sector - below!

profile_positions.description:
In this role my responsibilities included
* troubleshooting area equipment including the calciners, horizontal vacuum filters, pumps and dust conveying systems to minimize refinery production losses.
* continuously monitoring and controlling the final SGA product quality within contractual limits by manipulation of calciner operating conditions and negotiations with the other West Australian refineries (Wagerup and Kwinana).
* monitoring and where necessary reducing calciner Oxides of Nitrogen (NOx), carbon monoxide (CO) and Volatile Organic Compound (VOC) emissions.
* minimizing operating costs through calciner energy efficiency improvements and Bayer process chemistry in the context of daily operational management as well as developing the business cases
and FEL design work for capital projects including mass and energy balances and HAZOP studies
* supporting refinery equipment outage planning processes through production capability forecasting
* training refinery operating staff on new equipment and process management systems
* supporting the refinery goal of 'Zero Injuries' by undertaking housekeeping inspections, job safety observations and reviewing area standard work instructions to ensure they are up to date and include all relevant safety information.
